elements.content: Four new single crystals of sodium tetrakis(2-pyridinecarboxylato)Ln(III), where Ln is europium and terbium, with general formulas of Na[Ln(C6H4NO2)4]·2H2O were prepared from a reaction of solvent-mediated polymorph selection. All the crystal structures were determined by using temperature-dependent single crystal X-ray diffraction at 100(2) and 298(2) K. No phase transition was observed within this temperature range. Two isostructural compounds, IM (Eu3+ core) and IIIM (Tb3+ core), crystallize in the monoclinic space group C 2 h 6 - C2/c (No. 15) and the other two compounds, IIH (Eu3+ core) and IVH (Tb3+ core), in the enantiomorphic hexagonal space group D 6 3 - P6522 (No. 179). Both IM and IIH (or both IIIM and IVH ) are homeotypic. Each structure consists of an extensive network of organo-lanthanide complex and has extremely long-ranged interlayer distances, about 10 Å. The parallel interlayer in IM (or IIIM ) can be reconstructed into IIH (or IVH ) via 6-fold angularly step-staggered packing. Such a phenomenon of crystal packing strongly depends not only on the nature of the applied solvent system but also on long-range ordering of the organo-lanthanides. Transmission electron microscopy analysis of IIH and IVH reveals the absolute configuration of parallel helical assemblies. Their optical and magnetic data show the salient features of topospecific chirality over those racemic counterparts.

All the crystal structures were determined by using temperature-dependent single crystal X-ray diffraction at 100(2) and 298(2) K. No phase transition was observed within this temperature range. Two isostructural compounds, IM  (Eu3+ core) and IIIM  (Tb3+ core), crystallize in the monoclinic space group C 2  h  6 - C2/c (No. 15) and the other two compounds, IIH  (Eu3+ core) and IVH  (Tb3+ core), in the enantiomorphic hexagonal space group D 6 3 - P6522 (No. 179). Both IM  and IIH  (or both IIIM  and IVH ) are homeotypic. Each structure consists of an extensive network of organo-lanthanide complex and has extremely long-ranged interlayer distances, about 10 Å. The parallel interlayer in IM  (or IIIM ) can be reconstructed into IIH  (or IVH ) via 6-fold angularly step-staggered packing. Such a phenomenon of crystal packing strongly depends not only on the nature of the applied solvent system but also on long-range ordering of the organo-lanthanides. Transmission electron microscopy analysis of IIH  and IVH  reveals the absolute configuration of parallel helical assemblies. Their optical and magnetic data show the salient features of topospecific chirality over those racemic counterparts.

elements.content: This paper discusses the control of racemic and chiral modifications in lanthanide complexes. A switching between a parallel interlayer packing in a monoclinic (racemic) complex and a 6-fold angularly step-staggered interlayer packing in hexagonal (chiral) complexes is demonstrated using a simple solvent-mediated polymorph selection process.
elements.clean_text: This paper discusses the control of racemic and chiral modifications in lanthanide complexes. A switching between a parallel interlayer packing in a monoclinic (racemic) complex and a 6-fold angularly step-staggered interlayer packing in hexagonal (chiral) complexes is demonstrated using a simple solvent-mediated polymorph selection process.

elements.content: One of the most challenging aspects of crystal engineering of lanthanide complexes arises from the fact that most of them are polymorphic. To predict packing motifs and crystal structures of unknown compounds, we are not only required to rationalize the structural effects of a range of intermolecular forces, but we also need to account for the possible appearance of alternative packing patterns in compounds of interest. Chiral lanthanide complexes mainly resulting from the reaction of lanthanide ions and chelate ligands are of great interest due to their unique magnetic and optical properties. Unsymmetrical multidentate ligands containing hard donor atoms such as oxygen and nitrogen, which have high affinity to lanthanide ions, render great possibilities for the design of such multifunctional chemical architectures. In this regard, we have used 2,2′-pyridoin as a chelating organic molecule to make lanthanide complexes with chiral helicity since it readily undergoes metal-promoted benzylic acid type rearrangement to yield a 2-pyridinecarboxylate (pyc) ligand that tends to possess an one-dimensional (1D) chainlike structure.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

One of the most challenging aspects of crystal engineering of lanthanide complexes arises from the fact that most of them are polymorphic. To predict packing motifs and crystal structures of unknown compounds, we are not only required to rationalize the structural effects of a range of intermolecular forces, but we also need to account for the possible appearance of alternative packing patterns in compounds of interest. Chiral lanthanide complexes mainly resulting from the reaction of lanthanide ions and chelate ligands are of great interest due to their unique magnetic and optical properties. Unsymmetrical multidentate ligands containing hard donor atoms such as oxygen and nitrogen, which have high affinity to lanthanide ions, render great possibilities for the design of such multifunctional chemical architectures. In this regard, we have used 2,2'-pyridoin as a chelating organic molecule to make lanthanide complexes with chiral helicity since it readily undergoes metal-promoted benzylic acid type rearrangement to yield a 2-pyridinecarboxylate (pyc) ligand that tends to possess an one-dimensional (1D) chainlike structure.

elements.content: In this article, we report the polymorph-selective growth of crystals with racemic and chiral structures containing common heteronuclear Na[Ln(pyc)4]·2H2O (Ln = Eu3+, Tb3+; pyc = C6H4NO2) structural units whose packing event depends mainly on the unusual spatial arrangement of a two-dimensional (2D) brick wall motif. Moreover, we have found that their optical and magnetic properties are very sensitive to their structural chirality.
elements.clean_text: In this article, we report the polymorph-selective growth of crystals with racemic and chiral structures containing common heteronuclear Na[Ln(pyc)4]⋅2H2O (Ln = Eu3+, Tb3+; pyc = C6H4NO2) structural units whose packing event depends mainly on the unusual spatial arrangement of a two-dimensional (2D) brick wall motif. Moreover, we have found that their optical and magnetic properties are very sensitive to their structural chirality.

elements.content: A Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometer (Perkin-Elmer One/B system) was equipped with a KBr beam splitter and a liquid nitrogen cooled medium band MCT detector. The FTIR was also equipped with a micrometer clamp-equipped horizontal zinc selenide attenuated total reflectance (ATR) sampling accessory (Pike Technologies, MIRacle ATR) placed within the sample compartment. This instrument was allowed to purge Ar to minimize the spectral contribution due to atmospheric water vapor. Ten scans of symmetrical interferograms at 1 cm−1 resolution were accumulated for each spectrum. The ATR spectra of the culture medium were obtained from 4000 to 600 cm−1. In addition, ATR-FTIR spectra of the pure water, ethanol, picolinic acid, and α-pyridoin were measured under the same conditions for comparison (see ).
elements.clean_text:
Materials and Methods

Solid-State ATR-FTIR Spectroscopy Measurements

A Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometer (Perkin-Elmer One/B system) was equipped with a KBr beam splitter and a liquid nitrogen cooled medium band MCT detector. The FTIR was also equipped with a micrometer clamp-equipped horizontal zinc selenide attenuated total reflectance (ATR) sampling accessory (Pike Technologies, MIRacle ATR) placed within the sample compartment. This instrument was allowed to purge Ar to minimize the spectral contribution due to atmospheric water vapor. Ten scans of symmetrical interferograms at 1 cm-1 resolution were accumulated for each spectrum. The ATR spectra of the culture medium were obtained from 4000 to 600 cm-1. In addition, ATR-FTIR spectra of the pure water, ethanol, picolinic acid, and α-pyridoin were measured under the same conditions for comparison (see ).

elements.content: All the photoluminescence (PL) spectra (see Figure ) were recorded at 298(2) K with the solid-state single crystalline state. PL spectra of all single crystal samples (size: > 2.0 × 2.0 × 3.0 mm) were measured using a steady-state fluorometer (Edinburgh Instruments, FS920) with a 450W Xe lamp. He−Cd laser (λ = 325 nm) was used as an excitation light source when the emission was measured (see UV–vis spectra in ). The emission from the sample was collected and refocused to the emission monochromator with a 300 nm focal length. The emission spectra were collected with a PMT system (Hamamatsu R955). All spectra were taken at room temperature. The excitation laser powers were adjusted to the same power (about 16 mW) at the sample. The spectral resolution is 0.1 nm.

elements.content: PL anisotropy data (see Figure ) were measured by standard methods, including right angle excitation and emission collection with polarizers in both pathways. Briefly, PL anisotropy data for IM , IIH , IIIM , and IVH were collected with Fluorolog 3-11 (Jobin Yvon Inc.) spectrofluorometer employed Glan-Thompson polarizer. After the light emitted from the sample is collected with the photomultiplier (Hamamatsu R-928), the anisotropy data at each wavelength is calculated according to standard methods. r = I // − G I ⊥ I // + 2 G I ⊥ I // is the intensity of the emitted light when the emission polarizer is oriented parallel to the direction of the excitation polarization, while I ⊥ is the intensity of emitted light when the emission polarizer is perpendicular to the direction of the polarized excitation. The G factor is primarily a function of the wavelength of the emission spectrometer.

elements.content: Crystallographic data for IM , IIH , IIIM , and IVH (see Table ) were collected at 298(2) and 100(2) K, but they will be presented with the measured data at 100(2) K due to the solvent disorder at higher temperature. Each crystal was mounted and centered in the X-ray beam by use of a video camera. The crystal evaluation and data collection were performed on a Bruker APEX smart CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation and a detector-to crystal distance of 4.98 cm. The initial cell constants were obtained from three series of ω scans at different starting angles. Each series consisted of 20 frames collected at intervals of 0.2° in a 10° range about ω with an exposure time of 20 s per frame. The reflections were successfully indexed by an automated indexing routine built in the SMART program. The final cell constants were calculated from a set of strong reflections from the actual data collection. The data were collected using the full-sphere routine for high redundancy. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. The absorption correction was based on fitting a function to the empirical transmission surface as sampled by multiple equivalent measurements using SADABS software. The position of heavy atoms was found by the direct method. The remaining atoms were located in an alternating series of least-squares cycles and difference Fourier maps. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with full-matrix and anisotropic approximation, while isotropic approximation was employed to refine hydrogen atoms. All hydrogen atoms were placed at calculated idealized positions and were allowed to ride on the neighboring atoms with relative isotropic displacement coefficients. ORTEP-3 diagrams were drawn at the 80% probability level. For the compounds IIH and IVH , the observed systematic absences were consistent with space groups P61, P65, P6122, and P6522. Although the necessary choice is between the point groups 6 and 622, the chirality of rare earth coordination provides a clue to determine the correct enantiomorphic space group. The structure was solved in the space group P6522 by the direct method and refined on the basis of F 2 for all unique data using SHELXTL software. Refinements with other possible space groups such as P65 and C2221, under the relationship of a O = a H, b O = b H√3 and c O = c H, turned out to be satisfactory with a reduced data-to-parameter ratio. However, P212121 was not satisfactory, and no higher supergroup was observed in the temperature range from 100(2) to 298(2) K. The final refinement converged to R 1 = 0.03−0.05, wR 2 = 0.06−0.08, and S (GOF) = ∼1.00, and a model that did not involve disorder of any atomic positions except coordinated and noncoordinated solvent molecules. Since P6522 is a non-centrosymmetric space group, care was taken to determine absolute structure in which the final values of the Flack parameter were x = 0.01(1) for IIH and 0.03(3) for IVH . The highest residues were found around the position of lanthanide ions. After atomic positions of the framework atoms were determined, H2O positions in the framework channels were extracted from the difference Fourier map. The H2O sites were first positioned at peaks with maximal electron density, followed by analyzing their local environments. The site occupancy factors for O positions from the H2O molecules were fixed at 1.00 and the isotropic displacement parameters at ∼0.02 Å2 to get reasonable refinement. The number of water molecules/formula unit determined from structure refinement is 2.0 according to the charge balance and trigonal prismatic coordination of NaO6 at 100(2) K. The final model included anisotropic displacement parameters for Ln to refine O atoms in solvents anisotropically were successful. Details of the data collections and refinements are given in Table . The complete listings of atomic coordinates, bond distances, and bond angles are available in CIF formats. [Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC) Deposition Numbers: CCDC 658699, CCDC 658701, CCDC 607985, and CCDC 607988.]

HRTEM studies have been performed using a JEOL 2000 EX microscope operating at 200 kV combined with a higher angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF STEM) technique. Each suspension solution of nanosized single crystals was collected during the recrystallization processes after 2 days of reaction steps, (b) or (c) (see Scheme ). Samples were prepared by evaporating a drop of the particle solution deposited onto the carbon-coated TEM grids, which were stored in an Ar atmosphere.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility of the samples was measured with a SQUID magnetometer. The M versus T curve was measured in a 0.1 T field from 5 to 150 K and M versus H at 5 K from −5 to 5 T. We measured the exact weight of all the specimens at room temperature using a PC-equipped METTLER TOLEDO Com Weigh Measuring balance (version 2.52) with a reference uncertainty of 10−3 mg and a nominal weight of 1 mg. Single crystals of IM , IIH , IIIM , and IVH (∼1.0 × 1.0 × 1.5 mm) were mounted on a quartz tube with a diameter of 2 mm, whose magnetization data were collected in the parallel (//) and perpendicular (⊥) directions to an applied magnetic field. Diamagnetic corrections were done by the subtraction of diamagnetic moments of the quartz tube used for measurements. As shown in magnetization data for both Eu and Tb compounds show paramagnetic properties.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Property Measurements

The magnetic susceptibility of the samples was measured with a SQUID magnetometer. The M versus T curve was measured in a 0.1 T field from 5 to 150 K and M versus H at 5 K from -5 to 5 T. We measured the exact weight of all the specimens at room temperature using a PC-equipped METTLER TOLEDO Com Weigh Measuring balance (version 2.52) with a reference uncertainty of 10-3 mg and a nominal weight of 1 mg. Single crystals of IM , IIH , IIIM , and IVH  (~1.0 × 1.0 × 1.5 mm) were mounted on a quartz tube with a diameter of 2 mm, whose magnetization data were collected in the parallel (//) and perpendicular (⊥) directions to an applied magnetic field. Diamagnetic corrections were done by the subtraction of diamagnetic moments of the quartz tube used for measurements. As shown in  magnetization data for both Eu and Tb compounds show paramagnetic properties.

elements.content: As shown in Scheme , we first synthesized solvated samples containing a Na[Ln(pyc)4] unit by the reaction of 2,2′-pyridoin in NaOH/EtOH with LnCl3/EtOH. A total of 4 mL of 1 N NaOH solution was added dropwise to 40 mL of anhydrous ethanol containing 0.857 g (4 mmol) of α-pyridoin, which was subsequently treated with 1 mmol of LnCl3·6H2O in 10 mL of anhydrous ethanol. The mixed solution was stirred under O2 at room temperature until the initial color of mixture was changed from deep orange to pale yellow and finally to white. The resulting solid products were washed with anhydrous ethanol and centrifuged for 15 min at 3000 rpm (route a). In the crystallization process, an ethanol (route b) and a mixed pentane/ethanol (1:1, v/v) solvent (route c) were employed independently. The resulting products are hardly distinguishable by means of conventional characterization techniques such as UV–visible and ATR-FTIR spectroscopy, and powder XRD technique (see ) due to their structural similarity. Robust crystals were obtained from slow evaporation in both systems at room temperature, which typically take about 4 weeks. IM (or IIIM ) is readily transformed into IIH (or IVH ). In detail, 100 mg of IIH (or IVH ) was dissolved in a 10 mL of mixed ethanol/H2O (1:1, v/v) at 60 °C and was subsequently refluxed for 2 h under an Ar atmosphere, followed by evaporating very slowly the solvents at room temperature to yield IM (or IIIM ). Similarly, a 100 mg of IM (or IIIM ) in a mixed ethanol/pentane (1:1, v/v) solvent was refluxed for 4 h under Ar, followed by evaporating the solvents at room temperature to yield IIH (or IVH ). Both processes are reproducible in which the solvent molecules facilitate the structural transformation. All the crystals were well-shaped, which are suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction and successive characterizations.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

As shown in Scheme , we first synthesized solvated samples containing a Na[Ln(pyc)4] unit by the reaction of 2,2'-pyridoin in NaOH/EtOH with LnCl3/EtOH. A total of 4 mL of 1 N NaOH solution was added dropwise to 40 mL of anhydrous ethanol containing 0.857 g (4 mmol) of α-pyridoin, which was subsequently treated with 1 mmol of LnCl3⋅6H2O in 10 mL of anhydrous ethanol. The mixed solution was stirred under O2 at room temperature until the initial color of mixture was changed from deep orange to pale yellow and finally to white. The resulting solid products were washed with anhydrous ethanol and centrifuged for 15 min at 3000 rpm (route a). In the crystallization process, an ethanol (route b) and a mixed pentane/ethanol (1:1, v/v) solvent (route c) were employed independently. The resulting products are hardly distinguishable by means of conventional characterization techniques such as UV-visible and ATR-FTIR spectroscopy, and powder XRD technique (see ) due to their structural similarity. Robust crystals were obtained from slow evaporation in both systems at room temperature, which typically take about 4 weeks. IM  (or IIIM ) is readily transformed into IIH  (or IVH ). In detail, 100 mg of IIH  (or IVH ) was dissolved in a 10 mL of mixed ethanol/H2O (1:1, v/v) at 60 °C and was subsequently refluxed for 2 h under an Ar atmosphere, followed by evaporating very slowly the solvents at room temperature to yield IM  (or IIIM ). Similarly, a 100 mg of IM  (or IIIM ) in a mixed ethanol/pentane (1:1, v/v) solvent was refluxed for 4 h under Ar, followed by evaporating the solvents at room temperature to yield IIH  (or IVH ). Both processes are reproducible in which the solvent molecules facilitate the structural transformation. All the crystals were well-shaped, which are suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction and successive characterizations.

elements.content: As shown in Table , single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that IM and IIIM (or IIH and IVH ) are isostructural, and IM and IIH (or IIIM and IVH ) homeotypic. Since all the structures have a common formulas of Na[Ln(pyc)4]·2H2O, IM and IIH are representatively described in detail here. As can be seen in Figure , the pyc anion has two crystallographically distinctive coordination modes. Four pyc ligands (La ) are coordinated to the Ln core in a bidentate fashion, whereas a pyc ligand (Lb ) links in a monodentate manner. A common asymmetric unit of all the compounds comprises a Ln3+ ion, a Na+ ion, four La , a half Lb , and two coordinated water molecules bound to a Na+ ion. The core Ln3+ ion forms a typical nine-coordinated environment, while the Na+ ion has a six-coordinated environment including two water molecules. All the odd numbered oxygen atoms (O1, O3, O5, and O7) and four nitrogen atoms (N1, N2, N3, and N4) are directly connected to the Ln3+ core. As given in Figure b,c, a LnO4 unit excluding one oxygen atom (O8) in Ln−O−Ln bridging mode of Lb has pseudotetrahedral geometry, while the LnN4 unit has pseudosquare planar geometry. NaO6 is a uniform polyhedron of parallepiped-trigonal prism.

elements.content: All the Ln−O bond lengths are within the range of those observed for other nine-coordinate Ln3+ complexes, but have slightly narrower distribution, 2.318−2.443 Å (see Figures and ). To understand the bonding environments of the Ln core in more detail, we compared our results with those of three known cases: (1) the LnO9 case in asymmetric unit - occupying all the nine vertices of nine-coordinated polyhedron with oxygen atoms, (2) the LnO6N2 case in asymmetric unit - occupying six vertices of eight-coordinated polyhedron with six oxygen and two nitrogen atoms, and (3) the LnO5N4 (this study) case in asymmetric unit - occupying vertices of nine-coordinated polyhedron with five oxygen and four nitrogen atoms. This comparison is based on an empirical bond-valence sum analysis (BVS) owing to occasionally mismatched accompaniments of BVS in pyridine derivatives. The BVS calculations have become a valuable tool in crystal structure determinations particularly for the location of light atoms from the X-ray data, the rational distinction of isoelectronic ions, and the quick check for the plausibility of a structure solution. As a result of close examination with formal charge analysis, the empirical BVSs of 3.0 for (1), 2.5 for (2), and 2.0 for (3), respectively, were obtained from all Ln−O core motifs, while their sums of Na−O core motifs are about 1.0 in all the structures. As a simple estimation, each nitrogen atom contributes the bond-valence 0.25 in average directly to their Ln metal core. Actually, the Ln−N bond lengths are within the range of 2.536(6)−2.703(4) Å.

elements.content: As shown in Figure a, two orthogonal edges of LnO4 pseudotetrahedron are shared with two orthogonal edges of NaO6, forming an almost linear Na−Ln−Na angle array of 167.08(3)° for IM , 171.47(10)° for IIH , 167.40(5)° for IIIM , and 170.07(9)° for IVH . One pseudotetrahedron with edge-sharing triangular prisms extends to an infinite 1D foldamer via a solvent-anchoring to the outermost vertices of the trigonal prism, where an O9−O10 edge is parallel with an O1−O3 edge. The Ln−Na−Ln angle in common foldamer is 110.5(1)° for IM , 108.9(1)° for IIH , 111.1(1)° for IIIM , and 108.0(1)° for IVH . These infinite 1D chains are developed parallel to the b direction of the monoclinic space group in IM and IIIM , and to the ab plane of the hexagonal space group in IIH and IVH . The intra Ln−Ln distance in the 1D chain unit is 6.337(3) Å for IM , 6.322(1) Å for IIH , 6.399(2) Å for IIIM , and 6.301(1) Å for IVH . The inter Ln−Ln distance, however, should be examined for two points of view, a nearest next neighboring (NNN) interchain distance (x 1) and an NNN interlayer distance (x 2) due to a structural ambiguity of 3D construction from a definite 1D chain unit. The differences (Δx = x 2 − x 1) of predefined NNN distances are 0.55(1) Å [10.364(5) − 9.818(6)] for IM , −0.22(1) Å [10.237(2) – 10.461(1)] for IIH , 0.37(1) Å [10.199(3) – 9.828(3)] for IIIM , and 0.09 Å [10.408(1) – 10.315(1)] for IVH . This unusually interacted couple of infinite LnN4O5−NaO6 chain has a C 2 symmetry with “zigzag” brick topology, and its 2-fold axis is parallel to the [010] direction passing through the center of inter Ln−Ln metals, generating a 2D layer (see Figure ). These layers stack along the c-axis with the neighboring layers shifted by (1/2)b in IM and IIIM , forming a regular closest packing of cylinder-like infinite 1D chains to maximize the packing efficiency. In IIH and IVH , however, the equivalent layers stack along the c-axis with the neighboring layers angularly step-staggered by every 60° on the ab plane (see Figure ), which leads to an enhanced void volume. A distinctive feature of IIH and IVH is that the helical chains are independently connected together in separated each trigonal column by competing between axial and perpendicular NNN Ln−Ln motifs to form a homochiral 3D framework. The bond angles of Ln(x, y, z)−Ln(1 − y, 1 − x, 1/6 − z)−Ln(1 − x + y, 1 − x, 1/3 + z) along the c direction are 150.68(1)° for IIH and 151.93(1)° for IVH , which are quite linear, but each homochirality with left-handed topology ( M configuration) is discriminative.

elements.content: The 65 (or 61) screw axis passes through the center of the helical chain with a pitch of each lattice constant c. Macroscopically, two space groups have a close relationship in their lattice constants. A relationship of 1/2a M ≈ b H sin (π/3), b M ≈ a H, and 3c M ≈ c H leads to a M ≈ b O, b M ≈ a O, and 3c M ≈ c O, where a M, b M, and c M are lattice constants for monoclinic space group, a H, b H, and c H for hexagonal space group, and a O = a H, b O = b H √3, and c O = c H for orthorhombic space group. with this approximation, the packing volumes are enhanced about 4% (V O/V M), where V M is the unit cell volume of IM and IIIM and V O is calculated from a O × b O × c O of IIH and IVH . In accordance with this rigorous transformation from monoclinic structures of IM and IIIM into hexagonal structures of IIH and IVH , it confirms Wallach formalism parallel to thermodynamic stability of ΔS = R ln 2 (where ΔS is the entropy change from chiral to racemic counterpart and R is gas constant). This variation of packing volume can be categorized into a pervasive event of crystal engineering in order to predict polymorphs using the regular closest and angularly step-staggered packing. Experimentally, various solvent systems were employed to grow polymorphic phases due to the difficulty of a thermodynamically controlled reaction for polymorph separation. Regardless of the lanthanide ions, interestingly, the employment of ethanol solvent in the lanthanide complexes yields racemic crystals with monoclinic space group, while the use of mixed pentane/ethanol solvent leads to the growth of chiral crystals with hexagonal space group. Apparently, this polymorph-selective growth of crystals is strongly dependent upon the nature of mixed solvents, namely, the thermal behavior and controlled concentration of solvents. An important feature is that racemic and chiral structures can reversibly be switched by solvated molecules via a controlled solvent intercalation to the well-defined voids.

elements.content: The zigzag brick topology of 1D Na[Ln(pyc)4]·2H2O chain unit to generate 2D layer leads to racemic structures of IM and IIIM , but this topology with angularly step-staggered stacking generates parallel helical developments ( M configuration) along the c-axis of IIH and IVH . An absolute configuration of IIH and IVH should be taken into account because spontaneous resolution or partial spontaneous resolution may present in these cases due to the absence of any chiral auxiliary. It was, however, very difficult to refine the absolute configuration with X-ray diffraction technique alone in these cases. In order to convince the absolute configurations obtained from the X-ray diffraction data, we have performed the high resolution TEM analysis with single crystalline intermediates. The results are consistent with those of the X-ray diffraction studies. Since the TEM image contrasts depends primarily on the atomic weight (Z), the large difference between the Z values of Na (Z = 11) and Tb (Z = 65) would enable us to easily allocate the positions of the metal cations in the pyc complexes. Figure , panels a and b shows representative HRTEM images and corresponding fast Fourier transformations (FFT) of IIIM andIVH . A close look at the images reveals that the dark spots vary systematically over the images, related to the strong scattering of Tb ions relative to the weak Na signals. An average periodicity of about 6 nm was established in IVH along the c-axis, whereas about 2 nm in IIIM along the a-axis. Their lattice spacing and spot configurations coincide well with the corresponding structures derived from common zigzag-type 1D Tb−Na motif. The insets of Figure a,b are the ring patterns of IIIM and IVH , which are also consistent with the corresponding structures refined by the X-ray diffraction techniques. As shown in Figure c, the compound IVH consists of stacked hexagonal double layers of Tb and Na separated by ca. 3 nm, which is not distinguishable in the XRD pattern due to absent selection rules (i.e., d 002, d 003, and d 004 = 30.2, 20.1, and 15.1 Å, respectively). The diffused ring patterns are indicated “forbidden” diffractions of huge lattice spacing due to local solvent ordering or spontaneous resolution breaking. According to the analysis of FFT spots, the measured spacing about 0.72 nm (d 106 = 0.739 nm) can be assigned as the [106] plane which corresponds to the [001] plane. The helical pattern of NNN Tb−Tb motif could be cross-checkable with this analysis of FFT spots. The developed spots near [006] plane (d 006 = 1.01 nm) on the line of ca. 30° are actually “forbidden” due to structural model P6522 (or P6122) of chiral space group. The theoretical spots should be ones of [101] family. Estimated interplanar angles between [001] and [10x] are 28.3° (x = 2), 35.8° (x = 3), 42.0° (x = 4), 51.6° (x = 7), 55.2° (x = 8), 58.3° (x = 9), and 61.0° (x = 10), etc. The spots, however, are satisfied with a condition of d 106 < d 10x (x < 6). Therefore, spacing of developed spots must be originated from the alternative helical strands with a 30° local regularity. According to our structural models of IIIM and IVH , each area of bright spots corresponds to a staggered Na−Tb−Na or Tb−Na−Tb column. The separated distance is ca. 2 nm and is well matched with absent spacing (d 001 = 20.0 Å for IIIM and d 003 = 20.1 Å for IVH ), where disordered solvent molecules are therein, but these are not discriminative.

elements.content: It is well documented that PL spectroscopy is an effective tool for identification of core Ln motifs, together with any correlation with those environments in accordance with crystal structure analysis. The emission spectra arising from electric and magnetic dipole transitions were recorded for the four single crystals of Eu- and Tb-complexes (IM , IIH , IIIM , IVH ), showing typical characteristics of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ ions. The Eu3+ emission peaks arising from both complexes (IM , IIH ) are almost overlapped, which are well matched to transitions between a 5D0 excited-state to a ground-state of 7F J (J = 0 − 6) where peaks are arising from. For the two Tb3+ complexes (IIIM , IVH ), similar emission peaks are from a 5D4 to a ground state of 7F J (J = 6 − 0) (see full range PL spectra in ). The results suggest that luminescence is primarily sensitive to the lanthanide ion and less affected by the chiral helicity.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

It is well documented that PL spectroscopy is an effective tool for identification of core Ln motifs, together with any correlation with those environments in accordance with crystal structure analysis. The emission spectra arising from electric and magnetic dipole transitions were recorded for the four single crystals of Eu- and Tb-complexes (IM , IIH , IIIM , IVH ), showing typical characteristics of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ ions. The Eu3+ emission peaks arising from both complexes (IM , IIH ) are almost overlapped, which are well matched to transitions between a 5D0 excited-state to a ground-state of 7F J  (J = 0 - 6) where peaks are arising from. For the two Tb3+ complexes (IIIM , IVH ), similar emission peaks are from a 5D4 to a ground state of 7F J  (J = 6 - 0) (see full range PL spectra in ). The results suggest that luminescence is primarily sensitive to the lanthanide ion and less affected by the chiral helicity.

elements.content: For the anisotropy of each transition in the four samples, however, distinctive differences between racemic- and chiral-complexes are observed. The anisotropy at each wavelength is calculated by an equation of <r> = (I // − GI ⊥)/(I // + 2GI ⊥), where I // and I ⊥ are the polarized components parallel and perpendicular to the direction of polarization of the incident light and the G factor is primarily a function of the emission wavelength. As shown in Figure , PL anisotropy data clearly exhibit an unequivocal secondary structure-dependence on an intrinsic directionality of polymorphs and a priority of nondegenerate transitions between excited 5D0 state for Eu3+, unlike excited 5D4 state for Tb3+. The anisotropies of Eu- and Tb-complexes, IIH and IVH , not only have substantial value but also are noticeably affected by their crystal structures. The measured anisotropies of helical Eu-complexes have both positive and negative values presumably due to two different directionalities ( P and M configurations) but those of racemic congeners are nearly zero, clearly illustrating that the anisotropy is strongly affected by the secondary structure of the lanthanides.

elements.content: To assess magnetic coupling between lanthanide ion and oxygen radicals from pyc ligands, we have measured temperature- and field-dependent magnetization data of the lanthanide complexes using a SQUID magnetometer. For Eu-complexes, the observed magnetic moment is about 0.13 μB at 5 T and 10 K. The most likely origin of such a small moment is the oxygen radical, largely because the paramagnetism of Eu3+ decreases with temperature as the 7F1 population gradually vanishes. In contrast, the Tb-complexes have a moment of about 5.4 μB, which is slightly lower than the calculated value for J = 6 of Tb3+ ion and S = 1/2 of oxygen radical. The lanthanide complexes exhibit very interesting structure-sensitive magnetic behaviors. As given in Figure , temperature-dependent χT curves of racemic-type Eu- and Tb-complexes (IM , IIIM ) are nearly independent of temperature, while chiral counterparts clearly show temperature dependency. The nearly constant χT values implicate that the randomly disordered paramagnetic spin state is more favorable to the lamella structures than the helical ones. Another important thing to be addressed is the sign of the χT slope, which can provide a clue to understand the coupling mechanism between the Ln3+ spins and oxygen radicals. The negative Curie–Weiss constant for a chiral Tb-complex, shown in the inset, can be interpreted in terms of an antiferromagnetic interaction. On the other hand, a chiral Eu-complex has a positive value, indicating the presence of ferromagnetic interaction. These magnetic behaviors of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ ions are consistent with those found in other lanthanide complexes involving organic radicals with competing intrachain exchange interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

To assess magnetic coupling between lanthanide ion and oxygen radicals from pyc ligands, we have measured temperature- and field-dependent magnetization data of the lanthanide complexes using a SQUID magnetometer. For Eu-complexes, the observed magnetic moment is about 0.13 μB at 5 T and 10 K. The most likely origin of such a small moment is the oxygen radical, largely because the paramagnetism of Eu3+ decreases with temperature as the 7F1 population gradually vanishes. In contrast, the Tb-complexes have a moment of about 5.4 μB, which is slightly lower than the calculated value for J = 6 of Tb3+ ion and S = 1/2 of oxygen radical. The lanthanide complexes exhibit very interesting structure-sensitive magnetic behaviors. As given in Figure , temperature-dependent χT curves of racemic-type Eu- and Tb-complexes (IM , IIIM ) are nearly independent of temperature, while chiral counterparts clearly show temperature dependency. The nearly constant χT values implicate that the randomly disordered paramagnetic spin state is more favorable to the lamella structures than the helical ones. Another important thing to be addressed is the sign of the χT slope, which can provide a clue to understand the coupling mechanism between the Ln3+ spins and oxygen radicals. The negative Curie-Weiss constant for a chiral Tb-complex, shown in the inset, can be interpreted in terms of an antiferromagnetic interaction. On the other hand, a chiral Eu-complex has a positive value, indicating the presence of ferromagnetic interaction. These magnetic behaviors of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ ions are consistent with those found in other lanthanide complexes involving organic radicals with competing intrachain exchange interactions.

elements.content: The present results demonstrate the feasibility of selective growth of crystals with racemic and chiral-type structures using a simple resolution process. Apparently solvated molecules play a crucial role in the crystallization process of the polymorphic Eu3+ and Tb3+ compounds. Our comprehensive measurements clearly demonstrate that optical and magnetic properties of the lanthanide complexes are strongly dependent on the structural and magnetic chiralities. The anisotropy values of the lanthanides are clearly observed with substantial quantity despite of the large number of transition dipole moments of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ states. Moreover, magnetic behaviors depend on the nature of lanthanide ions as well as the chiral helicity. The racemic and chiral-type crystals would be useful for studying unusual spectroscopic characteristics in the millisecond time scale as well as investigating magnetic exchange interaction between lanthanides and organic radicals.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The present results demonstrate the feasibility of selective growth of crystals with racemic and chiral-type structures using a simple resolution process. Apparently solvated molecules play a crucial role in the crystallization process of the polymorphic Eu3+ and Tb3+ compounds. Our comprehensive measurements clearly demonstrate that optical and magnetic properties of the lanthanide complexes are strongly dependent on the structural and magnetic chiralities. The anisotropy values of the lanthanides are clearly observed with substantial quantity despite of the large number of transition dipole moments of the Eu3+ and Tb3+ states. Moreover, magnetic behaviors depend on the nature of lanthanide ions as well as the chiral helicity. The racemic and chiral-type crystals would be useful for studying unusual spectroscopic characteristics in the millisecond time scale as well as investigating magnetic exchange interaction between lanthanides and organic radicals.
